sub_subject.name: Reading, Phonics & Penmanship (Foundational Literacy)
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Reading, Phonics & Penmanship (Foundational Literacy) (Language Arts & Humanities)

objectives.objective_text: Identify root words within larger complex words.
Identify homophones (there/their/they're) correctly.
Identify the feelings of the characters.
Identify rhyming words in a simple poem or song.
Identify syllable breaks in multisyllabic spoken words.
Identify subtle sound shifts in dialects or accents.
Identify common digraphs (th, ch, sh) in written words.
Identify complex vowel teams (oa, ie, ough).
Identify the front and back of a book.
Identify basic punctuation marks (period, question mark).
Identify the parts of a book (title page, table of contents, index).
Identify when a mistake makes a sentence sound silly.
Identify the pauses in unison reading.
Identify bold words by reading louder.
Name the marks that tell us to stop.
Identify the end of a thought.
Identify difficult connections (like 'o' to 'r').
Name the "Pincher" fingers.
Identify tension in the shoulder.
Identify reversals (b vs. d).
Identify a book that tells a good story.
Name a book that is boring (textbook).
Identify literary quality in children's books.
Name the main character.
Identify the sequence without prompting.
Identify complex sentence structures by ear.
Identify synonyms for common words.
Identify "That reminds me of..."
Name a time I felt like the character.
Identify shared themes across books.
Identify how a character feels by their face.
Identify unstated causes of events.
Identify a tricky word.
Identify when the mind wanders.
Identify the most important thing.
Identify the theme.
Recall a new word from a story.
Recognize 'chunks' in words (like -ing or -and).
Recognize the 100 most common words instantly.
Recognize the 1,000 most common words instantly.
Recognize alliteration and assonance in spoken poetry.
Recall that practice helps us read smoother.
Observe tracking the line with a finger.
Recall that we stay together.
Observe the rhythm of the group.
Recall that we don't sound like robots.
Observe how punctuation tells us how to speak.
Recall that words group together.
Recall that cursive is faster.
Observe signatures.
Recall that the other hand holds the paper.
Recall starting letters at the top.
Recall that good books make ideas stick.
Observe beautiful pictures.
Recall the order of events.
Listen to a story.
Recall that we can read books that are too hard to read alone.
Observe new words in context.
Recall another book about the same thing.
Observe that stories are like real life.
Recall "I think... because..."
Recall the main idea.
Blend sounds to read simple words smoothly.
Read simple sentences fluently without stopping for every word.
Answer simple 'who' and 'what' questions about the story.
Match letters to their primary sounds (consonants and short vowels).
Decode simple CVC words (Consonant-Vowel-Consonant).
Defend the need for precise vocabulary over common words in academic writing.
Explain how listening builds vocabulary differently than reading.
Decode technical vocabulary in scientific or historical texts.
Explain how listening builds vocabulary.
Ask "What does that word mean?".
Guess the meaning from the picture.
Use a "fancy" word in a sentence.
Summarize how to use context clues.
Explain the meaning of a word based on the sentence.
Collect favorite words from books.
Explain why dictionary definitions sometimes differ from usage.
Defend the "incidental" learning of vocabulary over rote memorization.
Segment a written word into its individual letters/sounds.
Read words with consonant blends (bl, st, tr).
Write the sounds heard in a word in the correct order.
Blend syllables to read longer compound words.
Segment words into roots and affixes.
Read words with complex endings (-tion, -ture, -ious).
Break down a long word to spell it correctly.
Explain the rules for syllable division in English.
Defend the importance of precise articulation in public speaking.
Sound out unknown words letter by letter.
Use picture clues to help identify a difficult word.
Self-correct when a decoded word doesn't make sense.
Use context clues to determine the meaning of a decoded word.
Decode words with multiple syllables quickly.
Explain the meaning of a word based on its parts.
Defend an interpretation of a text based on precise word definitions.
Read 'rule-breaker' words that can't be sounded out (said, was).
Spell common sight words correctly in writing.
Spell high-frequency words correctly in all written work.
Read fluent prose without hesitation on common words.
Explain the difference between sight recognition and phonetic decoding.
Sit quietly and listen to a story.
Predict what might happen next.
Summarize the main plot points of a chapter read aloud.
Explain the motivation of a character.
Ask clarifying questions about confusing parts.
Defend the oral tradition as a valid form of literature.
Isolate the first sound in a spoken word (e.g., /d/ in dog).
Blend spoken sounds together to make a word (/c/-/a/-/t/ -> cat).
Segment a spoken word into its individual sounds.
Manipulate sounds in words (e.g., change /s/ in 'slip' to /c/ -> 'clip').
Distinguish between similar vowel sounds (short e vs. short i).
Explain how phonemic awareness aids in spelling unfamiliar words.
Defend the importance of oral tradition in preserving language sounds.
Decode multisyllabic words using prefixes and suffixes.
Explain why some words break standard phonics rules.
Defend the logic behind English orthography despite its complexity.
Track text from left to right and top to bottom.
Distinguish between a letter, a word, and a sentence.
Explain the function of paragraphs and indentation.
Use bold or italicized text to find important information.
Explain how headings and subheadings organize information.
Defend the importance of standard formatting for clarity.
Read words correctly without guessing.
Read at a talking speed (not too slow, not too fast).
Summarize the goal of fluency (reading like you speak).
Explain why skipping words changes the meaning.
Read a paragraph with fewer than 3 errors.
Explain how to handle multi-syllabic words while reading aloud.
Defend the need for accuracy in reading Scripture publicly.
Read together with the class.
Repeat a sentence after the teacher.
Summarize how listening helps us say words right.
Explain "Echo Reading" (I say, You say).
Match the volume of the leader.
Explain prosody modeling.
Defend the communal aspect of reading texts aloud.
Read with a happy or sad voice.
Make the voice go up at a question mark.
Summarize reading with feeling.
Explain why we pause at commas.
Change character voices in dialogue.
Explain the "melody" of a sentence.
Defend the importance of tone in communication.
Stop at a period.
Take a breath at a comma.
Summarize "Scooping" words into phrases.
Explain why we don't read word-by-word (choppy).
Read a long sentence without running out of breath.
Explain parenthetical remarks with voice modulation.
Defend the author's intent through proper pacing.
Trace loopy lines.
Summarize how to join lowercase letters.
Explain the slant of the letters.
Write own name in cursive.
Explain the personal nature of a signature.
Defend the continued relevance of handwriting in a digital age.
Hold the pencil with three fingers (Tripod).
Sit up straight with feet on the floor.
Summarize why good posture helps writing (less tired).
Explain how to tilt the paper for arm movement.
Adjust grip to avoid squeezing too hard.
Explain left-handed vs. right-handed paper positioning.
Defend the discipline of the body for intellectual work.
Draw straight lines and circles.
Write letters sitting on the line.
Space words with a "finger space".
Summarize the difference between capital and lowercase heights.
Explain "tall" letters vs. "falling" letters (g, j, p, q, y).
Write sentences with correct spacing.
Explain proper stroke order.
Defend the clarity of block lettering for forms/labeling.
Summarize what makes a book "Living" (ideas, not just facts).
Explain why we read whole books, not just snippets.
Choose a book by a single author with passion.
Explain the avoidance of "twaddle" (dumbed-down books).
Defend the use of narrative to teach science and history.
Tell what happened in the story.
Draw a picture of the scene.
Summarize the chapter in own words.
Explain the most important part.
Retell with detail (oral narration).
Explain why we narrate after one reading (attention).
Defend narration as the "act of knowing".
Sit quietly while mom or dad reads.
Summarize the benefits of hearing good language.
Discuss the story together.
Explain the concept of "The Great Conversation".
Defend the practice of reading aloud to older children/teens.
Summarize Text-to-Self connections.
Explain Text-to-Text connections (series or genre).
Explain the "Great Books" dialogue.
Defend the unity of truth across disciplines.
Guess what is in the box.
Predict the ending.
Summarize what "Reading between the lines" means.
Explain clues that lead to a guess.
Make a hypothesis about the plot.
Explain inductive reasoning in reading.
Defend an interpretation using textual clues.
Stop if it doesn't make sense.
Ask "Who is that?"
Reread a sentence.
Summarize checking for understanding.
Explain looking up a word.
Use context to fix a misunderstanding.
Explain metacognition (thinking about thinking).
Defend the need for slow reading of complex works.
Tell the short version.
Ask "What happened?"
Summarize a chapter in three sentences.
Explain the "5 Ws" (Who, What, Where, When, Why).
Generate questions for discussion.
Explain the prcis (formal summary).
Defend the main thesis of a book.
Connect segmentation skills to learning foreign vocabulary.
Analyze the phonemic structure of complex vocabulary words.
Apply decoding strategies to read unfamiliar academic vocabulary.
Analyze the nuance of literary vocabulary.
Interpret archaic or period-specific language.
Connect wide reading to verbal intelligence.
Analyze how prefixes change the meaning of a root word.
Interpret the structural components of academic terms.
Apply knowledge of cognates to understand new words.
Analyze the structure of a sentence to aid in decoding difficult terms.
Interpret words with Greek or Latin roots.
Connect decoding fluency to reading comprehension speed.
Analyze why certain words became high-frequency in English.
Interpret the usage of common academic transition words (however, therefore).
Connect sight word fluency to reading stamina.
Compare the read-aloud book with the movie version (if applicable).
Analyze the tone and voice of the narrator.
Interpret auditory cues (pause, emphasis) to understand meaning.
Connect the themes of the read-aloud to current events.
Connect sound patterns to the rhythm and meter of poetry.
Apply the 'silent e' rule to read long vowel words.
Analyze the etymology of words to explain their spelling.
Interpret the pronunciation key in a dictionary.
Connect phonics rules to the history of the English language.
Compare fiction and non-fiction text features.
Analyze the layout of a textbook or article.
Interpret footnotes, endnotes, and citations.
Connect the formatting of a text to its genre.
Analyze reading speed (Words Per Minute) vs. comprehension.
Interpret self-correction as a sign of good reading.
Connect fluency to cognitive load (freeing the brain to think).
Analyze the benefits of choral reading for confidence.
Interpret the phrasing modeled by the teacher.
Connect choral reading to responsive readings in church.
Analyze how pitch changes meaning (sarcasm vs. sincerity).
Interpret the mood of a passage through voice.
Connect intonation to comprehension.
Analyze the syntax to determine natural pauses.
Interpret the dash and semicolon in oral reading.
Connect phrasing to the logic of the sentence.
Connect letters without lifting the pencil.
Analyze the flow of handwriting.
Interpret historical documents written in cursive.
Connect fine motor skills to brain development.
Analyze the ergonomics of writing.
Interpret the effect of fatigue on handwriting quality.
Connect arm movement vs. wrist movement.
Analyze consistency in letter size.
Interpret the legibility of text.
Connect neatness to courtesy for the reader.
Analyze the narrative style of non-fiction living books.
Interpret the "atmosphere" of a book.
Connect the author's enthusiasm to the reader's interest.
Analyze the connections between this story and others (Written Narration).
Interpret the motivations of characters in the retelling.
Connect narration to composition skills.
Analyze the shared family culture built by reading.
Interpret themes discussed during read-alouds.
Connect listening comprehension to reading comprehension.
Compare a book to a historical event (Text-to-World).
Analyze how prior knowledge helps understanding (Schema).
Interpret current events through a literary lens.
Connect universal human experiences in literature.
Analyze the author's implication.
Interpret character motivation not explicitly stated.
Connect subtle details to the bigger picture.
Analyze difficult syntax by breaking it down.
Interpret footnotes or marginalia.
Connect comprehension to reading speed adjustments.
Analyze the structure of an argument through summary.
Interpret the difference between plot summary and analysis.
Connect questioning to the Socratic method.
Evaluate the role of phonology in language evolution.
Evaluate the author's choice of complex vocabulary.
Evaluate the precision of word choice in literature.
Evaluate the morphological structure of complex medical or legal terms.
Evaluate the impact of repetitive language in a text.
Evaluate the rhetorical effectiveness of a spoken speech.
Evaluate the effectiveness of different phonics instruction methods.
Evaluate the layout and design of a publication.
Evaluate the trade-off between speed and accuracy.
Evaluate the unification of voices in liturgy.
Evaluate the effectiveness of a speaker's inflection.
Evaluate the impact of poor phrasing on listener understanding.
Evaluate the aesthetic quality of penmanship.
Evaluate the relationship between posture and focus.
Evaluate handwriting against a standard model.
Evaluate the literary merit of a biography.
Evaluate the accuracy and completeness of a narration.
Evaluate the moral impact of shared stories.
Evaluate the relevance of an ancient text to modern life.
Evaluate the validity of a prediction.
Evaluate the clarity of a text.
Evaluate the conciseness of a summary.
Synthesize decoding skills to read ancient or primary source documents.
Construct a sophisticated vocabulary beyond high-frequency words.
Synthesize a broad sight vocabulary to read at a collegiate speed.
Construct sentences using sophisticated vocabulary derived from reading.
Synthesize lexical breadth with expressive writing.
Construct new words using established blending patterns (neologisms).
Synthesize blending skills to read fluent, expressive prose.
Construct a glossary of decoded technical terms for a research paper.
Construct a critique of an audiobook narrator's performance.
Synthesize auditory information with written notes.
Construct phonetic transcriptions of spoken words.
Synthesize phonemic knowledge to learn pronunciation in a foreign language.
Construct a linguistic explanation for irregular spellings.
Synthesize phonics knowledge to decode archaic or dialectal texts.
Construct a properly formatted academic paper (MLA/APA style).
Synthesize visual and textual elements in a document.
Construct a personal reading goal for WPM.
Synthesize automaticity with decoding skills.
Construct a Readers' Theater script for group performance.
Synthesize auditory learning with visual text tracking.
Construct a dramatic reading of a poem.
Synthesize vocal variety with textual analysis.
Construct a marked-up text for performance reading.
Synthesize grammatical structure with oral delivery.
Construct legible paragraphs in cursive.
Synthesize speed and legibility.
Construct a workspace conducive to good penmanship.
Synthesize physical mechanics with artistic expression.
Construct a handwritten letter.
Synthesize visual spacing with orthography.
Construct a reading list of living books for a topic.
Synthesize knowledge gained from living books into narration.
Construct a detailed summary essay.
Synthesize multiple sources in a complex narration.
Construct a family reading plan.
Synthesize auditory learning with critical discussion.
Construct a comparative literature essay.
Synthesize personal experience with textual evidence.
Construct an argument based on inference.
Synthesize foreshadowing with outcomes.
Construct a summary of a dense theological or philosophical text.
Synthesize annotation strategies.
Construct an abstract for a paper.
Synthesize inquiry-based learning with reading.
